title: 112_hr6207
content: The "Children's Health Task Force Act of 2012" may be cited as the Act. It establishes a Task Force on Environmental Health Risks and Safety Risks to Children. The "Children's Health Task Force Act of 2012" establishes a permanent Task Force on Environmental Health and Safety Risks to Children, with key officials from various government agencies serving as members. The Task Force on Environmental Health and Safety Risks to Children includes key officials from various government agencies, as well as stakeholders invited by the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. The Task Force on Environmental Health and Safety Risks to Children recommends Federal strategies for addressing environmental health and safety risks to children in the United States, including action plans, initiatives, and recommendations for improving cross-agency implementation. The Task Force on Environmental Health and Safety Risks to Children recommends Federal strategies for addressing environmental health risks and safety risks to children, including cross-agency budgeting, research agenda coordination, partnerships among different sectors, public outreach enhancement, and data system strengthening. The Task Force on Environmental Health and Safety Risks to Children submits biennial reports to the President and Congress, detailing strategies, accomplishments, national priorities, and research updates on addressing environmental health and safety risks to children in the United States. The Task Force on Environmental Health and Safety Risks to Children submits biennial reports to the President and Congress, including updates on Federal research findings, information from Federal departments and agencies, recommendations from the Children's Health Protection Advisory Committee, and stakeholder submissions. Additionally, the Task Force may submit additional reports and updates as needed, which will be made publicly available. The Task Force on Environmental Health and Safety Risks to Children meets annually, publishes meeting notices in the Federal Register, and maintains detailed meeting minutes. The Task Force on Environmental Health and Safety Risks to Children must keep detailed meeting minutes, including a record of attendees, discussions, conclusions, and reports. These minutes must be made available to the public for inspection and copying, and the Co-Chairs must certify their accuracy. Executive Order 13045 terminates the existing Task Force on Environmental Health Risks and Safety Risks to Children. Executive Order 13045 (April 21, 1997) is terminated, and appropriations are authorized for carrying out the Act in fiscal year 2013 and subsequent years.
